questions.text: Which of the following fatty acid present in fish oil is known for its cardio-protective function?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eicosapentaenoic acid Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA): ω3 fatty acid Present in fish-oil Known for its cardio-protective action EPA inhibits the formation of thromboxanes (TX2) which are potent platelet aggregators. Hence, the intake of ω3 fatty acids promotes platelet disaggregation.

questions.text: Phospholipases are hydrolases that act on phospholipids to release fatty acids and are important mediators of signal transduction pathways. Snake venom contains which of the following phospholipases?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phospholipase A2 Snake venom Contains Phospholipase A2 (PLA2) PLA 2 hydrolyzes the ester bond at position 2 of phospholipids in the plasma membrane of various cells, g., erythrocytes. PLA 2 also affects neurons at the pre-synaptic or post-synaptic cleft to cause neurotoxicity. Phospholipases A1 A2 C D Present in Pancreatic fluid Present in Erythrocytes and snake venom Major toxins secreted by bacteria Role in Mammalian signal transduction

questions.text: Omega-3 fatty acids are found in “oily” fish and are considered beneficial for heart health. Food containing which one of the following would not fall into this category?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

γ-Linolenic acid Delta system—when counting starts from the carboxy end Omega system—when counting starts from the methyl group (omega C) ω3 fatty acids are α-Linolenic acid Eicosapentaenoic acid Docosahexaenoic acid

questions.text: All of the following are true about sphingolipids, EXCEPT? Amphipathic in nature Fatty acids form two hydrocarbon tails Sphingosine is an amino alcohol with a double bond Sphingomyelin is a phospholipid Ceramide + Complex sugars → Sphingomyelin Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, five are correct Sphingosine is an amino alcohol with one double bond and two hydroxyl groups In glycerophospholipids , two hydrocarbon tails are formed by fatty acids. In sphingolipids , One of the tails is formed by fatty acid Other is formed by sphingosine. Ceramide - N-acyl sphingosine (the fatty acid is linked to the amino group of sphingosine via an amide bond)

questions.text: A component of a “lipid panel” for a patient is triglyceride. If a triglyceride is hydrolyzed, which of the following will not be a product of this hydrolysis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sphingosine Triacylglycerols Neutral lipids Made up of glycerol and fatty acids. Linoleic acid and palmitic acid are fatty acids. Sphingosine Amino alcohol Component of sphingolipids.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child had normal growth and development for the first few months. Still, growth started deteriorating gradually along with symptoms such as deafness, blindness, atrophied muscle, inability to swallow, and seizures. During the fundus examination, a cherry red macula was also noticed in both eyes. Suspecting sphingolipidoses, the physician tested for globosides and gangliosides levels and found that both were increased. Based on this finding, what is the most accurate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sandhoff’s disease The child is exhibiting the symptoms of either Tay–Sachs or Sandhoff’s disease, both of which are sphingolipidoses . However, in Tay Sach’s disease, only gangliosides will be increased, and globosides degradation should be normal. But in Sandhoff’s disease both globosides and gangliosides will accumulate. GM2 Gangliosidoses Disease Deficient enzyme Lipid accumulating Clinical features Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A Gangliosides ● Mental retardation, Blindness, ● Muscular weakness, ● Cherry-red spot Sandhoff disease Hexosaminidases A and B Golobosides and gangliosides ● Macrocephaly ● Hyperacusis ● Cherry-red spot

questions.text: All of the following disorders are inherited in autosomal recessive mode, except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fabry’s disease All Sphingolipidoses are autosomal recessive except Fabry’s which is X- linked recessive

Extraedge:

Fabry’s Disease X-linked recessive, so only males affected Triad of peripheral neuropathy, Angiokeratoma, and Hypohidrosis Fabry’s crisis occurs (similar to sickle cell crisis) – pain and swelling in proximal joints

questions.text: Multiple sclerosis is a disease characterized by chronic inflammation. Research data indicate that susceptibility to multiple sclerosis may be inherited. This disease is characterized by a loss of which of the following lipids?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phospholipids and sphingolipids Multiple sclerosis Demyelinating disease causing loss of myelin membrane sheets of nerves in white matter. Consequently, brain white matter eventually looks like gray matter. Loss of Phospholipids & Sphingolipids from white matter. CSF shows ↑ phospholipid levels and sphingolipids

questions.text: Major body lipids are chemical esters of fatty acids and alcohol. Which one of the following lipids does not contain any alcohol?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DHA Alcoholic group is found in Glucocerebrosides, Sphingomyelin, and Lecithin except for DHA. DHA (Docosa Hexanoic Acid) 22C fatty acid with six double bonds. No alcohol is present Glucocerebrosides & Sphingomyelin contain Sphingosine alcohol. Lecithin contains Glycerol alcohol.

questions.text: Correct match of disease and enzyme defect:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Krabbe’s – β Galactosylceramidase Disease Enzyme Deficiency Niemann Pick disease Sphingomyelinase Farber’s disease Ceraminidase Gaucher’s disease β-Glucosidose or β-Glucocerebrosidase Krabbe’s disease β-Galactosidase for Galactosyl Ceramidase Fabry’s disease α- Galactosidase Sandhoff’s disease Hexosaminidase B Tay Sach’s disease Ηexosaminidase A GM1 gangliosidosis (or generalized gangliosidosis) β – Galactosidase Metachromatic Leukodystrophy Αrylsulfatase A or Cerebroside Sulfatase Fucosidosis α- Fucosidase

questions.text: Match the following: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-f, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d Saturated fatty acids: No double bond is present. A number of hydrogens in the case of saturated fatty acids is double the number of carbons Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids: More than one double bond is present PUFAs/EFA Omega-3 Omega–6 1. Cervonic Acid (22 C, 6=) (Fish Oil) 1. Gamma – Linolenic Acid (18 C, 3=) (Oil of evening primrose) 2. Alpha – Linolenic Acid (18C, 3=) (Flexed Oil, Soybean Oil) 2. Linoleic Acid (18C, 2=) (Safflower Oil) 3. Timodonic Acid (20 C, 5=) (Fish Oil) 3. Arachidonic Acid (20 C, 4=) (Animal Fats)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a product of complete hydrolysis of Sphingomyelin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ceramide Sphingomyelin comprises sphingosine alcohol, one fatty acid, one phosphate, and one choline. So, sphingosine alcohol , one fatty acid , one phosphate, and one choline are products of complete hydrolysis of sphingomyelin. This fatty acid can be palmitic acid. So palmitic acid can be a product of complete hydrolysis. But Ceramide = Sphingosine + Fatty acid. So, ceramide CANNOT be a product of complete hydrolysis. It is a product of partial hydrolysis .

questions.text: C 17 H 31 COOH is the formula of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Linoleic acid In case of a saturated fatty acid, a number of hydrogens are double the number of carbons. In this fatty acid, the number of carbons is The number of hydrogens is 32. In the case of saturated fatty acid, if carbons are 18, hydrogen must be 36 (double). So, there is a loss of 4 H (which means two double bonds). So, this is Linoleic acid (18 C, two double bonds). Note WITH REGARDS TO OTHER OPTIONS Refer to attached Mantra

questions.text: Which is the most essential fatty acid?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Linoleic acid Most essential fatty acid is Linoleic acid (18-C, two double bonds. Linoleic acid is the precursor of omega-6 FAs. It can give rise to γ-Linolenic acid and Arachidonic acid (PUFAs). Polyunsaturated fatty acids / Essential Fatty Acids (EFA) Cannot be synthesized in the due to the absence of enzymes that can introduce double bonds beyond the 9th carbon in humans. 2 essential fatty acids in diet → Linoleic and α-Linolenic acid. But, the essential fatty acid → Linoleic acid (because it can synthesize Arachidonic acid).

questions.text: A one-week-old infant presented with relentless vomiting, watery green diarrhea, abdominal distension, and failure to thrive. Further examination showed hepatosplenomegaly and increased cholesterol esters and TG levels in plasma. X- ray showed calcification of adrenals. The child most probably have a defect in which of the following enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acid lipase The calcification of adrenals is highly diagnostic of Wolman Disease. It is a cholesterol ester storage disease due to lysosomal acid lipase deficiency. As a result of lipase deficiency, excess triglycerides will not be degraded and will accumulate in cells. Other C/F Vomiting Watery green diarrhea Hepatosplenomegaly Rx - Enzyme replacement therapy

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Deficiency of acid maltase causes Pompe's disease (a glycogen storage disease) with features such as hypotonia, cardiomegaly in muscles, hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia in the liver Total lysosomal acid phosphatase (LAP) deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder with clinical features such as intermittent vomiting, lethargy, hypotonia, opisthotonos, and terminal bleeding in early infancy.
